author: trent_vanepps
content: what made you change your mind on ETH?

author: trent_vanepps
content: I used to work in architecture and design as well! welcome

author: sabnock
content: A variety of things. I went fairly in depth in my application. I was originally a Bitcoin maxi. I thought its simplicity was what helped it to work so well. I thought having a Turing-complete language like Eth does introduced more flaws than benefits. I didn't see too many use cases for smart contracts either. Eth seemed like Bitcoin but with lots of extra bells and whistles but lacking in novelty. I also worked in cybersecurity briefly in university and read about security vulnerabilities in smart contracts and such.. That began to change once we got into last Summer and saw many DeFi projects built on Ethereum which began offering services typically done by traditional financial intermediaries as well as reading about Eth 2.0 which seeks to streamline many aspects of the protocol which began to convince me that the developers of Eth really were serious about building something that worked, was secure, and revolutionary.

author: sabnock
content: I hope that answers your question.

author: somaditya.
content: Need advice. I have been out of touch with math for some time, though I studied engineering in college. What specific topics would you recommend to brush up to understand the math in the yellow paper? Thanks.

author: sabnock
content: Maybe some discrete math. The fourth section goes through the notation Wood uses throughout. Yet he provides a few simple equations prior to this. The yellow paper cheat sheet I think would probably help you a lot if you can sort of look at them both side by side.

author: somaditya.
content: By fourth section you mean "Blocks, State and Transactions"? And by cheat sheet did you mean this one: https://github.com/benjaminion/YellowPaper_CheatSheet/blob/master/YPCheatSheet.pdf ? sorry if i

author: somaditya.
content: pardon if i asked silly ques

author: owleksiyowpckcr
content: FWIW, I don't think you need to refresh any specific area. As long as you understand notation, you should be good

author: sabnock
content: I agree with that

author: sabnock
content: Yeah, that's the cheat sheet

author: sabnock
content: And I'm wrong, I meant the third section
